headline: Report: Health care divide sharpens Michigan GOP Senate race between Rogers and Smith
summary: The Michigan Republican U.S. Senate primary has exposed a policy split on the Affordable Care Act: frontrunner Mike Rogers seeks full replacement of the marketplace healthcare system, while challenger Bernadette Smith advocates a two-year extension of premium subsidies. This debate over healthcare policy impacts hospital funding, doctor availability, and patient access, while creating political divisions within the GOP ahead of the 2026 elections.

headline: Minnesota attorney general’s legal opinion could threaten some county agreements with ICE
summary: A new Minnesota Attorney General opinion states that state law prohibits sheriffs from independently entering into 287(g) agreements with ICE; such contracts require county board approval, potentially jeopardizing existing agreements with eight Minnesota sheriff's offices. The Crow Wing and Cass County boards confirmed they did not approve their agreements, while six other counties could not immediately confirm approval status. The guidance builds on a February opinion that prohibits detaining individuals solely on ICE detainers, even in counties with 287(g) agreements. Ramsey County Attorney John Choi requested the opinion in November. The Attorney General's office declined to specify the impact on non-compliant counties.

headline: Whooping cough, high absences from illnesses close some Iowa schools
summary: Iowa's Department of Health and Human Services surveillance identified four schools with ≥10% illness rates, prompting closures including Davis County for whooping cough and Moulton-Udell where 30% were affected by influenza A; State Medical Director Dr. Robert Kruse is urging vaccination and staying home when sick, though just 26.7% of Iowans have received flu vaccines this season following the state's first flu death in November.

headline: Prairie Band Potawatomi intends to ditch $30M ICE contract, chairman announces
summary: The Prairie Band Potawatomi Tribe is moving to cancel a $29.9 million contract with ICE to design immigrant detention centers, with Tribal Chairman Joseph Rupnick condemning the agreement by comparing immigrant detention to historical Native American reservations; the Tribal Council fired leadership of its business arm, Prairie Band LLC, after the contract became public, and Rupnick stated the tribe will prioritize moral obligations over economic development despite risks to future government contracts, while Kansas currently operates three immigrant detention facilities with a potential fourth pending.

headline: Utah Forward Party’s first-of-its-kind preference poll picks a winner to replace Sen. Thatcher
summary: The Forward Party of Utah's preference poll on Dec. 12, 2025, selected Emily Buss to fill the Senate District 11 vacancy with 625 votes (47.21% approval) from 1,324 voters using an approval voting system open to all registered voters regardless of party affiliation. This open process yielded significantly higher participation than typical caucus-based replacements, which usually involve around 150 delegates. Party officials have formally submitted Buss's name to Gov. Spencer Cox for appointment, positioning her to become Utah's only third-party legislator. The Utah Republican Party stated it would not challenge the appointment despite concerns about Sen. Dan Thatcher's party switch and the process used. Forward Party leaders view this transparent, inclusive poll as a potential model for future midterm replacement processes statewide and nationally.
